importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the public was informed about the NTSB report on Brett James' plane crash.
The year Brett James achieved a major breakthrough with the song 'Jesus, Take the Wheel,' which marked the beginning of his rise as a prominent songwriter in the music industry.
The date of the fatal plane crash, when Brett James was piloting his plane and it crashed into a field in Franklin, North Carolina.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The specific time and day of the crash event, indicating the exact moment when the incident occurred and when the NTSB began its investigation.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter, was killed in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while attempting to land on runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' during flight, leading to the crash.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, but failed to tune to the common traffic advisory frequency, resulting in a communication breakdown.
The plane, a Cirrus SR22T, flew over the runway and then descended into a left turn before descending into a spiral and crashing.
No mechanical issues were found in the aircraft wreckage, indicating the crash was likely due to pilot error or communication failure.
Brett James was a highly influential songwriter who collaborated with major artists such as Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Keith Urban, and co-wrote Kenny Chesney’s hit 'Out Last Night'.

namedEntities.name: Brett James

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He was the pilot and sole person on the flight team who tragically died in the plane crash, making him the central figure of the incident.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB issued a preliminary report on the crash, providing official findings and analysis of the flight sequence and cause of the accident.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A single-engine, general aviation aircraft model.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location where the plane crash occurred, marking the site of the fatal incident.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The target landing point that Brett James was attempting to use for a visual approach, which became a key element in the communication and navigation failure.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to announce their position when no tower control is present.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to tune to the CTAF, resulting in a breakdown in communication with air traffic control and contributing to the accident.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brett James worked with Bon Jovi, highlighting his broad industry appeal and collaborations with top-tier artists.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with major artists like Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, and Keith Urban, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, while attempting to land on runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) reported that the Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' due to a failure to maintain communication with air traffic control—specifically, not tuning to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF)—despite being cleared for a visual approach. No mechanical issues were found in the wreckage. The incident underscores both the risks of aviation and the loss of a major creative figure in the music industry.
title: Brett James' Plane Crashes After Communication Failure, NTSB Reports
